column5: Tips for what to do there
column6: Photo spot tips, ideas of good places to get nice instagram photos
column7: Summary of reviews and ratings with links to sources

column5: Try their signature pancakes or eggs benedict. It's close to your hotel and has a cozy, trendy vibe to kick off your trip.
column6: Get a shot of the beautifully plated brunch dishes with the rustic-chic table decor.
column7: 4.8/5 on Google Maps. Reviewers rave about the friendly service and all-day breakfast standards.

column5: Explore masterpieces by Greco and Velazquez. It is located in a stunning 17th-century palace right near your hotel so it minimizes walking early on.
column6: The ornate courtyards and cloisters provide stunning, elegant backdrops without the heavy crowds of the Alcazar.
column7: 4.7/5 on Google Maps. Highly rated for its peaceful atmosphere and impressive Andalusian art collection.

column5: Stock up on bottled water, some cheap local wines, jamón, and snacks for the hotel room. Great value and just a short walk from the museum.
column6: N/A - just a practical grocery stop!
column7: 4.2/5 on Google Maps. Reliable chain, appreciated by locals and tourists for its wide selection of affordable local produce.

column5: Sit outdoors in the square if possible. Order regional specialties and share 4-5 tapas plates among the three of you. Very casual and highly rated.
column6: The outdoor seating captures the quintessential vibrant Sevillian street dining vibe.
column7: 4.5/5 on Google Maps. Visitors love the robust wine list, homey feel, and authentic traditional food.

column2: Shopping on Calle Sierpes at [Natura](http://googleusercontent.com/map_location_reference/8) & nearby boutiques
column5: Stroll down Seville's main pedestrian shopping street. Natura has great boho clothes and cute gifts/souvenirs. Keep an eye out for independent boutiques along the side streets.
column6: Capture candid walking shots down the bustling, awning-shaded Calle Sierpes.
column7: 4.3/5 on Google Maps. Shoppers like the variety of clothes, home goods, and relaxing store ambiance.

column5: Walk the rooftop pathways. Try to time it exactly for golden hour as the sun sets over the city for the best experience.
column6: The winding wooden walkways with the city skyline in the background make for the ultimate iconic Instagram photo.
column7: 4.4/5 on Google Maps. Praised as a unique modern architectural contrast to the old city with the best panoramic views.

column5: A wildly popular and super affordable classic tapas bar just minutes from Las Setas. Put your name on the chalk waitlist and grab a drink outside.
column6: Snap the bustling, lively atmosphere outside with people mingling over drinks while waiting for a table.
column7: 4.3/5 on Google Maps. Known for generous portions, great sangria, and an unbeatable vibe.

column2: Breakfast at [LA CRÈME DE LA CRÈME Brunch & Breakfast. Crepes, Galettes, Gofres.](http://googleusercontent.com/map_location_reference/14)
column5: Grab some French pastries, crêpes, or quiches at the sidewalk tables near Las Setas before heading across the river to Triana.
column6: Snap photos of your coffee and pastries with the modern Las Setas structure towering in the background.
column7: 4.5/5 on Google Maps. Loved for its cozy cafe vibe and excellent sweet treats.

column5: Wander the indoor bazaar. It's a great place to buy spices, olive oil, or cured meats as souvenirs. Stop at the stalls inside for a casual midday bite.
column6: The colorful fruit, meat, and cheese stalls make for great vibrant, authentic travel photography.
column7: 4.4/5 on Google Maps. Reviewers recommend it for its authentic local feel and great tapas stalls inside.

column5: Triana is historically famous for pottery. Buy authentic, hand-painted ceramic plates or bowls here as high-quality, beautiful souvenirs.
column6: The vibrant tiled facade of the building itself is stunning and famous on social media.
column7: 4.8/5 on Google Maps. Highly praised for its massive selection, quality craftsmanship, and history.

column2: Walk back across Puente de Isabel II & River Views
column5: Enjoy the walk back to the city center. You can walk along the river path towards the Torre del Oro.
column6: The view from the bridge looking down the Guadalquivir river towards the Torre del Oro is perfect.
column7: N/A

column2: Wander Barrio Santa Cruz & Early Dinner at [Bodega Santa Cruz Las Columnas](http://googleusercontent.com/map_location_reference/20)
column5: Get lost in the narrow Jewish Quarter streets. Have a cheap and very casual standing tapas dinner here. It gets busy, so going early avoids the massive crowds.
column6: The extremely narrow alleys of Santa Cruz with overhanging balconies and orange trees are incredibly photogenic.
column7: 4.4/5 on Google Maps. Famous for its buzzing atmosphere, fast service, and cheap, delicious bites.

column5: Head back into the center for some of the best traditional churros con chocolate in the city. You eat them thick and doughy here.
column6: The old-school interior with hanging hams and tiled walls creates a perfect moody Spanish aesthetic.
column7: 4.4/5 on Google Maps. Locals and tourists alike agree they serve some of the best churros in Seville.

column5: An old coal warehouse turned into an impromptu flamenco venue. It's not a formal, sit-down show—just grab a pitcher of sangria, sit on the benches, and enjoy the raw performance.
column6: The rustic indoor courtyard and fiery performers make for great low-light candid videos.
column7: 4.3/5 on Google Maps. Beloved for its lack of pretension, free entry, and completely authentic, casual vibe.

column5: Enjoy a healthy, aesthetic brunch to fuel up for a heavy sightseeing day.
column6: The beautifully presented avocado toasts and modern interior are great for a food photo.
column7: 4.8/5 on Google Maps. Top-rated for its excellent brunch options and friendly staff.

column5: Spend a couple of hours exploring the gardens and Moorish palace. Booking tickets weeks ahead is strictly required as it sells out!
column6: The Baths of Lady María de Padilla (underground arches) and the intricate Courtyard of the Maidens are stunning.
column7: 4.7/5 on Google Maps. Described as breathtaking and a must-see landmark of Moorish architecture.

column5: It opens at 2:30 PM on Sundays. Climb the Giralda tower (it has ramps, not stairs) for beautiful views of the city.
column6: The Patio de los Naranjos (Courtyard of the Orange Trees) inside the cathedral grounds is gorgeous.
column7: 4.8/5 on Google Maps. Visitors are awestruck by its massive scale and the views from the bell tower.

column5: Rent a rowboat in the canal or just sit and watch the flamenco dancers that often perform in the square.
column6: Literally everywhere. Sit on the ceramic tiled alcoves representing different Spanish provinces, or on the intricate bridges.
column7: 4.8/5 on Google Maps. Universally loved as one of the most spectacular public squares in the world.

column5: This sprawling, romantic park is attached to Plaza de España. It's full of fountains, gazebos, and orange trees. Perfect for cooling down.
column6: Find the Mount Gurugú waterfall or the hidden tile-covered pavilions for some magical photo backdrops.
column7: 4.8/5 on Google Maps. Locals love walking the shaded paths in the late afternoon.

column5: A modern, slightly hip tapas spot with creative dishes before you grab your bags. Casual but feels like a fun final dinner. Gets busy so arrive right when they open for dinner service.
column6: The industrial-chic decor and quirky art make it a very Instagrammable dining spot.
column7: 4.4/5 on Google Maps. Highly praised for modern twists on tapas, like their risotto and patatas bravas.
